ai-mn71:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
ai-mn71:2.1_0: Now at that time the wanderer Vacchagotta was residing in the Single Lotus Monastery of the wanderers.
ai-mn71:3.1_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
ai-mn71:3.3_0: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Vesālī.
ai-mn71:3.4_0: Why don’t I visit the wanderer Vacchagotta at the Single Lotus Monastery?”
ai-mn71:4.1_0: Vacchagotta saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
ai-mn71:4.2_0: and after seeing (him), he said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-mn71:4.5_0: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
ai-mn71:4.6_0: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”
ai-mn71:4.7_0: He sat on the seat spread out
ai-mn71:4.8_0: while Vacchagotta took a low seat and sat to one side.
ai-mn71:4.9_0: Then the wanderer Vacchagotta said to the Buddha:
ai-mn71:5.2_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:
ai-mn71:5.3_0: “Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.”’
ai-mn71:5.4_1: ‘The ascetic Gotama claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus: ‘Can you have confidence in the Buddha? Are there any legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism?’
ai-mn71:5.5_1: ‘The ascetic Gotama claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus: ‘They claim to be untrue, and all have come out.’”
ai-mn71:6.1_0: “So how should we answer so as to repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? How should we explain in line with his teaching, with no legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism?”
ai-mn71:6.2_0: “‘The ascetic Gotama has the three knowledges.’ Answering like this you would repeat what I have said, and not misrepresent me with an untruth. You would explain in line with my teaching, and there would be no legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism.
ai-mn71:7.1_0: And whenever I want, I recollect my many kinds of past lives.
ai-mn71:7.2_1: I remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so I recollect my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
ai-mn71:8.1_0: And whenever I want, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn ...
ai-mn71:8.1_1: and I understand how beings are reborn according to their (good and bad) actions.
ai-mn71:9.1_0: And I have realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. I live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-mn71:10.1_0: ‘The ascetic Gotama has the three knowledges.’ Answering like this you would repeat what I have said, and not misrepresent me with an untruth. You would explain in line with my teaching, and there would be no legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism.”
ai-mn71:11.1_0: When he said this, the wanderer Vacchagotta said to the Buddha,
ai-mn71:11.2_0: “Master Gotama, are there any laypeople who, without giving up the fetters of suffering?”
ai-mn71:12.1_0: “But are there any laypeople who, without giving up the fetter of lay life, go to heaven when the body breaks up?”
ai-mn71:12.2_0: “There’s not just one hundred laypeople, Vaccha, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that who, without giving up the fetter of lay life, go to heaven when the body breaks up.”
ai-mn71:13.1_0: “Master Gotama, are there any Ājīvaka ascetics who make an end of suffering when the body breaks up?”
ai-mn71:14.1_0: “But are there any Ājīvaka ascetics who go to heaven when the body breaks up?”
ai-mn71:14.2_0: “Vaccha, I recollect my ninety-one eons back even a single day, except for a single day or night.
ai-mn71:14.3_0: and he taught the efficacy of deeds and action.”
ai-mn71:15.1_0: “That being so, Master Gotama, so it is like a bonfire.”
ai-mn71:15.2_0: “Yes, Vaccha, it is well-proclaimed, even as much as a bonfire.”
ai-mn71:15.3_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn71:15.4_0: Satisfied, the wanderer Vacchagotta was happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn71:15.5_0: The first chapter on the three knowledges is finished.
